title: Dusty Springfield’s Former London Home Now Asking £11.5 Million
text:
The Art-Deco-style London home that was once home to the singer Dusty Springfield has just been on the receiving end of a £3.5 million (US$4.3 million) discount, listing records show.



The five-story house on Aubrey Walk in the city’s posh Holland Park neighborhood has been asking £11.5 million since last week. It first hit the market in March 2018 for £14 million.



More: Frank Lloyd Wright’s Last Home Goes up For Auction

Spanning 7,200 square feet, the seven-bedroom property is the combination of two terraced homes joined into one, according to the listing with estate agency Savills.



It has a 35-foot-long indoor swimming pool, a sauna, a gym and a party room. There’s also a master bedroom suite with a sitting room, a dressing room and direct access to the roof terrace, a garden, and two off-street parking spaces.



“As the former home of legendary singer, Dusty Springfield, it brings together a sense of history and cultural importance with the architectural merits of a home created to reflect Art Deco design principles,” Savills said previously in a news release.



The brokerage could not immediately be reached for a comment.



From Penta: Barron Hilton Leaves 97% of His Fortune to the Family Foundation

Springfield, who died in 1999 at the age of 59, lived in the home between 1968 and 1972, according to a plaque affixed to the facade of the house, which was unveiled by the late Bee Gees star Robin Gibb in 2011.



The London native is a member of both the U.S. Rock and Roll and U.K. Music halls of fame and lived at the property when her most famous hit, “Son of a Preacher Man,” was released in 1969.



Mansion Global could not determine the seller of the home, or when they purchased it.
